summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, commanding an unnamed recipient to appear before the grand jury on August 20, 2019, and to produce all materials relating to Jeffrey Epstein. The subpoena includes a rider detailing the recipient's rights and specifying the scope of requested materials, including electronic communications and documents.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Issued the grand jury subpoena as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subpoena commands the production of all materials relating to Jeffrey Epstein in connection with an alleged violation of federal statutes.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, is issuing a subpoena for materials related to Epstein as part of a grand jury investigation into alleged violations of federal law.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance
events.description: The subpoena commands an unnamed recipient to appear before the grand jury at the United States Courthouse in Manhattan to testify and give evidence regarding alleged violations of federal law.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Borough of Manhattan, City of New York, New York
One St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: A grand jury subpoena was issued on August 15, 2019, for an appearance on August 20, 2019, in the Southern District of New York.
The subpoena demands the production of all materials relating to Jeffrey Epstein, including text messages, emails, social media messages, documents, and notes.
The investigation involves alleged violations of 18 U.S.C. §§ 371, 1001, and 1519, which relate to conspiracy, false statements, and destruction of evidence.
The subpoena explicitly covers electronically stored materials on devices like computers, cellphones, and cloud accounts, even if located in foreign jurisdictions.
The recipient is advised of their rights, including the right to refuse to answer self-incriminating questions and the right to consult with an attorney.
